diagnoses: Drug reaction (e.g., to antibiotics or NSAIDs)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (Coxsackievirus Infection)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reactions (e.g., drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction (including drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms - DRESS)
Cancer with pericardial and pleural involvement

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by autoantibody production that can lead to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In some people, it can also affect a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In people with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules called granulomas, consisting of inflamed tissues, form in certain organs of the body.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder in which the immune system destroys the body's red and white blood cells, as well as platelets. This can lead to autoimmune hemolysis, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It is considered a type of autoimmune rheumatic disease. Skin changes may include a violet coloration or dusky red rash.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that may result in changes to the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs. The disease can cause skin thickening, stiffness, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that manifests features of several connective tissue diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can cause a wide array of symptoms including those mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels. It causes changes in the walls of blood vessels, such as thickening, weakening, narrowing, and scarring. This can affect various organ systems, including the brain, causing seizures.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis characterized by high fevers, rash, and joint pain. It may also affect internal organs, such as the heart and lungs, leading to pericardial effusions among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Cerebritis
diagnoses.description: A complication of systemic lupus erythematosus where the disease affects the brain or central nervous system. It can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including seizures.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Bronchitis, especially chronic bronchitis, is a key component of COPD.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.rationale: Symptoms such as hypersensitivity reactions and hyperactivity (due to difficulty breathing) can be related to asthma.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause hypersensitivity reactions and irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.rationale: Both chronic kidney disease and COPD are risk factors for the development of heart failure.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic kidney disease can result in anemia, which might exacerbate symptoms of other conditions due to reduced oxygen carrying capacity.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a common complication of chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Diabetes is a leading cause of chronic kidney disease and can also exacerbate other conditions mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic kidney disease can cause or worsen hypertension, and hypertension can exacerbate conditions such as heart failure.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.rationale: A condition resulting from chronic kidney disease, which can aggravate or lead to further health issues.

diagnoses.name: Renal Osteodystrophy
diagnoses.rationale: A complication of chronic kidney disease involving bone metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism).

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, possibly leading to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body produces too many platelets, leading to a risk of thrombosis but can also paradoxically present with thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation in the skin, mucous membranes, and often in organs such as the lungs, liver, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of blood clots (thromboembolic disease) and may also lead to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. It can also cause thrombocytopenia and is associated with thromboembolic events.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells (leading to thrombocytopenia), brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and produces too little thyroid hormone, leading to a wide range of symptoms, though it's less commonly associated with the combination of these specific symptoms but can lead to depression.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that develops in the thyroid gland, which can lead to hyperthyroidism in its early stages.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets in the blood.

diagnoses: Tick-borne illnesses (other than Lyme, e.g., Babesiosis)
Common cold or upper respiratory infection
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Exacerbation with Allergic Component
Asthma (in the context of wheezing specifically)
Urinary tract infection (for the symptom of incontinence, particularly in the elderly)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief interruption of blood flow to part of the brain, causing temporary stroke-like symptoms such as aphasia, numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical emergency caused by a blockage or rupture of blood vessels in the brain, leading to symptoms such as numbness or weakness on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms depending on its location, including headache, seizures, numbness, nausea, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body, leading to symptoms like numbness, weakness, balance issues, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, confusion, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by severe hypertension leading to brain dysfunction, characterized by headache, nausea, seizures, confusion, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs, potentially affecting the nervous system and causing a wide range of neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Nonepileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizure-like episodes that are not due to epilepsy but rather psychological conditions such as stress, characterized by various symptoms including convulsions and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms but is frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Tension Headache
diagnoses.details: A common type of headache characterized by pain around the head, scalp, or neck, often associated with muscle tightness.

diagnoses.name: Viral Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges, caused by a viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Meningitis
diagnoses.details: A severe infection of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord. This condition requires urgent medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.details: A series of relatively short but extremely painful headaches every day for weeks or months at a time.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.details: An uncommon type of stroke caused by bleeding on the surface of the brain. It's a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.details: A condition related to high pressure in the fluid around the brain. This can cause headaches and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.details: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the lining of your arteries, most often the arteries in the temples, which can cause severe headaches.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing weakness and tiredness among other symptoms.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as nonscarring alopecia, pleural effusion, and lymphopenia. Chilblains (Lupus pernio) can also be observed in patients, especially in cold environments.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory disease known to cause skin rashes and nonscarring alopecia. While lymphopenia and pleural effusion are less common, they can occur as part of the systemic inflammation associated with the condition.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Pernio (Sarcoidosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Not to be confused with chilblains lupus, Lupus Pernio in the context of sarcoidosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that can cause skin lesions similar to chilblains, lymphopenia, and pleural effusion due to granulomatous inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE. It can cause nonscarring alopecia, lymphopenia, and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Advanced cases can present with pleural effusion and lymphopenia, and occasionally feature nonscarring alopecia. Although chilblains are not a classic symptom, rheumatoid vasculitis could mimic chilblain-like lesions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This disease primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands but can also lead to nonscarring alopecia and lymphopenia. Pleural effusion can occur in more severe systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: This connective tissue disease can cause skin changes that may appear similar to chilblains. It can also result in pleural effusion and, less commonly, in lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.rationale: CLL can lead to significant lymphopenia due to the crowding out of normal lymphocytes. Pleural effusion can develop in advanced stages. While nonscarring alopecia is not characteristic, systemic effects of CLL might lead to hair changes.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing megaloblastic anemia, pernicious anemia can sometimes cause nonscarring alopecia and has been associated with autoimmune conditions that might present with lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS is a direct cause of lymphopenia due to the destruction of CD4+ T cells. While pleural effusion can result from opportunistic infections, nonscarring alopecia may occur due to either the infection itself or secondary to treatments.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Felty's Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. The combination of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, seizures, and pericarditis could be manifestations of SLE.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and can be associated with other autoimmune disorders, which might lead to neurological complications or involve the heart.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis (arterial or venous) and/or pregnancy-related complications along with the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can cause thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, neurological symptoms such as seizures, and cardiac involvement including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by clot formation in small blood vessels throughout the body, leading to low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), hemolytic anemia, renal dysfunction, neurological symptoms including seizures, and occasionally cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases involving the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. In systemic forms, it can affect internal organs, possibly leading to pericarditis, and in severe cases mediating hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neurologic complications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In rare cases, it can cause neurological symptoms (including seizures), hematological abnormalities such as hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder of the immune system primarily affecting people of all ages and characterized by fever, splenomegaly, cytopenias (including thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia), and neurological symptoms. It may also affect the heart.

diagnoses.name: Malignancy-Associated Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: Certain malignancies, including leukemia and lymphoma, can present with hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and other systemic symptoms, including seizures and pericardial disease.

diagnoses.name: Infection-Associated Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: Various infections, including viral, bacterial, and parasitic infections, can present with hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and possibly lead to seizures and pericarditis due to systemic inflammation or direct infection of the central nervous system or heart.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While RA primarily affects joints, it can also cause systemic symptoms, including hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, pericarditis, and rarely, neurological manifestations such as seizures.

diagnoses: Epilepsy (due to potential CNS involvement in systemic diseases)
Cancer (e.g., lung cancer or breast cancer)
